dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swinging doors open as the CAMERA TRACKS THROUGH them and barroom. It's lunchtime on November, 21, 1932, and the pl Westerners, mostly civilians but also some scattered sail singing "If I Had My Way," a pop ballad from 1913. We hav line of the chorus ("If I had my way, dear, forever there hardly matters:

dialogues.text: (singing lustily) A garden of roses for you and for me ... We PAN OVER to a piano keyboard where a burning cigarette on the next-to-last key. The pianist, accompanying the si butt and takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: TRIO
dialogues.text: A thousand and one things, dear, I would do ... We PAN OVER to the trio standing in a corner by the swing ugly, heavyset Westerners, two men and a woman. Someone t from off screen and the guy in the center fails to catch over to pick it up off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: TRIO
dialogues.text: Just for you, just for you, just for you. Another coin is thrown. This time, the guy on the left fa coin falls toward the floor with a loud metallic clank. T at the floor. We PAN DOWN just long enough to reveal a sp singers’ feet, then PAN BACK UP to the singers who reluc retrieve that particular coin. Never once during all this note.

dialogues.speaker: TRIO
dialogues.text: If I had my way, you would never grow old, And sunshine I'd bring every day ... On the word "day," a female patron approaches the heavy w question in her ear. Conveniently, there is a pause in th enough for the singer to reply:

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (brusquely) First door to your left, dearie. The female patron departs. We TRACK DOWN the crowded bar and a bartender toasting one another with huge glasses of pouring drinks for other sailors and their "dates"; vario women wearing the latest styles; uniformed chauffeurs; sh crew of various nationalities; etc. At one point, we brie carrying away the spittoon to retrieve the coin.

dialogues.speaker: TRIO
dialogues.text: You would reign all alone Like a queen on a throne, If I had my way. The song ends. Patrons applaud. We PAUSE at a middle-aged mixing a complicated drink. He grins and speaks to an uns at the bar, just off screen.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I haven't made one of these since the Fourth of July. In the background, we hear the trio begin a new song, ano one from 1918: “Till We Meet Again." The bartender takes drink's aroma and adds some more ingredients.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I was makin' one when the quake hit "Frisco. The bartender stirs the drink expertly and glances around

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Believe me, friend, I wouldn't go to all this trouble for any of these foreigners. With great pride, he adds a few finishing touches, pours glass and tops it off with an olive. The unseen patron's pick up the glass but the bartender raises a finger at hi

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Uh uh. Gotta wait a minute to let  the oil sink in. The patron withdraws his hand. Tossing a lemon slice behi catching it in midair, the bartender twists it with a flo glass. He inspects the drink closely, glances at the patron, the slice another grand twist before proudly sliding the glas Simultaneously, we hear the trio conclude their song to m

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: There you are, partner. You can tell your grandchildren about that one. Finally, we catch our first sight of the patron, DAN HARD thirtyish American man, as he puts the glass to his lips. drink he's bumped into from behind by a woman with her ba drink spills out and ends up on the floor. Dan turns angr wears a big floppy hat.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Say, what in the name of--?! The woman, a dark-haired American beauty named JOAN AMES, two come face to face. She, too, has spilled some of her eyed with anger. But as soon as their eyes meet, their at Both are somehow instantly smitten. And both realize they are holding the same obscure cockta In the background, we hear the pianist play the film's bi theme. After a pause, Joan finds her voice first.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Why, I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (a slight grin) I'm so glad.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (off his glass) Such a beautiful drink, too.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Paradise cocktail. (glances at his) Seem to be a few drops left.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (steadily) Always the most precious, the last few drops. That's luck.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (surprised) Yes. (beat) Uh, my name is Dan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Mine's Joan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Dan. They shake hands like old friends.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: May we, er, drink to our meeting?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: We should. (raises her glass) Here's... Here's "hail and farewell."

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Oh, that seems a bit ruthless. Let's say, uh-- Abruptly, two German voices drift in from the crowd -- ap sailors saying "till we meet again" to each other -- "Auf wiedersehen!" -- Dan glances in their direction, then tur raises his glass, inspired.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Auf wiedersehen. Joan looks at Dan sadly for a beat and then agrees:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Auf wiedersehen. They swallow their drinks, never taking their eyes off on his empty glass by the stem and slowly turns it upside-do puzzled, as Dan smashes the top of the glass against the drops the stem on the countertop where it rolls back and He grins at Joan who promptly responds in kind, smashing placing her stem on top of his, much to his surprise and delight. of the crossed stems. Dan gallantly tips his hat to Joan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: And so. Dan appears ready to leave but Joan puts an arm on him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Please. Shall I introduce you to my friends? Joan gestures to some people crowded behind her at the ba them and thinks it over but decides against it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I think not. Luck has allowed us a few drops of a Paradise cocktail--

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: And that would destroy the charm. You're right. Let's trust luck will come again. Joan puts her hand in Dan's. They stare into each other's moment. A dark look crosses her face. Her eyes waver and, she abruptly turns her back on him, as if he were suddenl Dan looks thoughtful and puzzled but takes it in stride. for the swinging doors. Joan turns and stares, watching h Joan's friends notices her interest and watches, too.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Known him long?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Ever so long.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I - I can't quite remember.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: (wryly) Better skip a few cocktails, darling. Joan watches sadly as Dan exits out the saloon's swinging just outside and turns back to look over the tops of the @ moment, he raises a hand in farewell. At the bar, Joan forces a smile and waves at Dan, just as up a happier tune and her friends crowd around her.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Come on, everybody. How about a little drink to Joan?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER FRIEND
dialogues.text: (hands Joan a drink) Joan, we're drinking to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: To Joan, dear. Joan, distracted by her friends, turns her back on Dan - any of the following: At the swinging doors, Dan - his hand still raised - sudd fear. His face clouds over, his eyes lower -- and he slow raises his other hand. It looks as if he's surrendering. And he is. We PAN DOWN as one of the doors swing open briefly to rev pistol pointed into Dan's side. We PAN UP to show the guy holding the pistol: a tough-loo man named STEVE BURKE.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: It's been a long chase, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (never losing his cool) Yes. What detained you? Burke leans in to pat down his captive.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Never mind the wisecracks. Dan catches a whiff of Burke's breath.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Still on the garlic, huh? Burke, insulted, backs off a little.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Well, nevertheless, it looks like you're out of luck this time.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (nods) Apparently. Dan desperately knocks the gun out of Burke's hand.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: of the gun hitting the pavement outside the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE
dialogues.text: struggle momentarily but Burke is the bigger man and Dan -- one punch in the jaw from Burke knocks him silly and d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke easily pushes a stunned Dan into a nearby wall like handcuffs himself to Dan, then shakes his captive violent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Come out of it! Dan regains consciousness, blinks at Burke, looks down at unhappily, and nods, reluctantly accepting the situation.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Okay, you win.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I always win. If you try to pull another break like that on me, I'll deliver you in a basket. Let's go. The two men pull their sleeves over the cuffs in a vain e inconspicuous as they start walking away from the saloon. brief, backward glance at the swinging doors, Burke stoop pistol, pocketing it. As they walk leisurely down the str passersby gawk and point at the two handcuffed men.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, now what?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: The boat. And then, uh, San Quentin.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Can I get my clothes?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Oh, they're on the boat.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Considerate.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (rubs his sore jaw) You know, I thought I ditched you way back in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: When I left 'Frisco, the chief said to me, "Steve, don't come back alone.” And he knew I wouldn't. Burke abruptly stops and stares at something off screen. forward, is jerked back.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I'll be a son of a sea cow. Dan and Burke watch as SKIPPY, a tipsy little American ma and bow tie, waits for a Chinese shop owner to turn his instantly snatches an alarm clock from a display and smoothly hides But, just as instantly, the alarm clock goes off, ringing shop owner turns to look at Skippy who rolls his eyes in returns the clock to its proper place, giving it a light ringing as Skippy staggers drunkenly out of the shop and encounte

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Well, if it ain't the light-fingered Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (a happy drunk) Hello, Dan!

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (to Skippy) So this is your hide-out. Hong Kong must be pretty soft.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (nods) I like it fine.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, ya better walk around that U.S.A. of America like it was a swamp.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (to Dan) It's gettin’ so a guy can't go nowheres nowadays without bumpin' into all sorts of people.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Duluth wants you, Detroit wants you, Sacramento wants you.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: I'm wanted everywhere and welcome nowhere. I'm just a vagabond. (spots the hand- cuffs, to Dan) Ohhh, that's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You can't win all the time.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (to Dan, leading him away) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything I can do for you here, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (off Burke) You might poison him. Dan and Burke walk off down the street. Skippy calls afte

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Hey, flatfoot! Burke looks back at Skippy with annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Tell those bulls I'm an alien! Ha ha ha ha! Ha ha ha ha ha ha. Skippy's laugh is even more irritating than he is. The ha -- Burke peeved, Dan understandably glum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud boat whistle blows. A sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: "STOPOVER IN HONOLULU"
dialogues.text: We DISSOLVE TO a brief glimpse of the railing on the line DISSOLVE TO Dan and Burke, still cuffed, as they approach lean against it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Stateroom is like a Turkish bath. Thanks for the outing. They mop their faces with handkerchiefs.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn't stand it myself.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thanks anyhow. (off the handcuffs) Say, how long? The cuffs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm takin' no chances. They broke five of my pals when you escaped.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, that wasn't right. They did all they could. They were shooting at me for three blocks.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it's lucky for you I wasn't among ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes ... Dan's attention is caught by something: a sailor on the o deck, locking the railing into place.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ... undoubtedly. Dan glances around and finds that his hand rests near the of the railing they are leaning against. He looks thoughtful Burke.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I may as well tell you now, I'm not such a good sailor.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Hmph! Get seasick, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Well, ya better enjoy everything while ya can, good or bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I suppose that includes being harnessed to you, garlic and all. Stung again, Burke is about to say something, then change

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, you better stand it and like it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ‘rraid I can't agree to like it. Suppose this ship were to sink. Imagine my embarrassment to be found dead anchored to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ship ain't goin' to sink.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Oh? They've been known to.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Well, listen, sucker, when it does, I'll make you a little present of this. Burke pulls the handcuff key out of his vest pocket, show pockets it again.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, I used to swim around a pier like that. Remember your kid swimming days?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (increasingly irritated) No.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Didn't you ever have a boyhood? Can't you swim?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I was wondering what you'd do if you were a cop in Venice.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Is that supposed to be a funny crack?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, it has its humorous side. Without Burke seeing, Dan rapidly unlocks the railing mec railing hard to make it swing free, then jumps backward o dragging Burke with him as he falls. The two disappear over the si CUT WIDE as Dan and Burke fall backward into the water be together. They hit the surface with a splash and disappea

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan and Burke bob to the surface. Dan forces Burke's body digs around in Burke's vest pocket for the handcuff key. to find it and unlock his cuff as the two men struggle. B up for air but Dan forces him down again. Somewhere above, a someone shouts, "Man overboard!"

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: Officers and passengers rush to the ship's side to see wh

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan looks up to see:

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: A crowd gathering at the railing, peering down at him.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: With all those people watching, Dan has no choice but to the water by his hair.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: An even larger mob gathers.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan reluctantly puts an arm around Burke and starts swimm

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) It's all right, I've got him!

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: Among the passengers watching with concern is none other down at the two men in the water, failing to recognize Da

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan struggles toward shore with an unconscious Burke in t sees:

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK, (TELEPHOTO ZOOM SHOT FROM BELOW)
dialogues.text: Joan, wearing her big floppy hat, leans over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan sees Joan (and her hat) and smiles in recognition. He

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: The crowd of onlookers, grouped near a raised anchor, wat

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan reaches a wooden pier and helps Burke on to a floatin

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Here ya are. Reach for the log. Hold on. Burke, regaining consciousness, grips the log as Dan pull Straddling the log, Dan helps Burke out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd at the anchor watches in relief.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: Dan and Burke sit on the log. Dan rises.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Lucky for you I knew where that key was.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (still dazed) Yeah. Thanks. Dan helps Burke to a nearby ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan puts on dry clothes as Burke, already changed, sits b and holstering his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Hey, you know, somebody must have left that rail unfastened. Leanin' there and, all of a sudden, we're in the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (dryly) Yes. We ought to sue the company.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I still can't see why you saved my life with what's facing you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Ah, suppose we don't discuss that.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, I - I kind o' feel like I ought to do you a little favor.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What? For a little thing like your life? Dan hears the click of the handcuffs behind him and glanc direction. PAN OVER TO Burke holding the open handcuffs i

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what you can do.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are not particularly becoming to the well-dressed man. ‘Sides, once this ship's at sea, there's no chance for a getaway. Kind o' tough on both of us to be ironed. What do you say? Burke looks at the cuffs and thinks it over. After a beat

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: All right, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (surprised but pleased) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: But if you try to pull a fast one on me, I'll knock you off cold. Is that understood?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I ain't kiddin’.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, I couldn't suspect you of that. Burke gives Dan a double take. Dan looks amused.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, it's kind of stuffy in here. All right if I go on deck?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (casually) Sure. Dan grabs a cap and heads for the door. Burke rises and f jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: But I'll go along with ya. Dan nods in reluctant agreement and the two men exit the

dialogues.speaker: A NEON SIGN
dialogues.text: shaped like an arrow. It reads: "To gangplank" We PAN OVER AND DOWN from this to the PURSER'S STATION wh middle of a conversation with the uniformed purser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an important message to deliver to her and, like an idiot, I forgot her last name. Her first name is "Joan."

dialogues.speaker: PURSER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, but--

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (gesturing) She's about, uh-- Oh, she's about so tall. Jet black hair and large brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PURSER
dialogues.text: Well, without her last name, it'll be awfully hard for me to find her. During this conversation, we PAN OVER to Burke who watche under the gangplank sign, shaking his head in disbelief. direction of the gangplank as he hears a noisy crowd.

dialogues.speaker: THE GANGPLANK
dialogues.text: is being unhooked from the ship. A huge crowd of well-wis waving to passengers on deck and chattering noisily. Runn crowd is Skippy who races up the gangplank just as it is pulled the ship ahead of the two Hong Kong policemen who are cha relieved, sits in the doorway where the gangplank was anc and waves to the policemen who, left stranded at the dock nightsticks at him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (salutes the police) You must come and see us sometime! Skippy, sitting in the gangplank doorway, laughs his inim laugh and waves good-bye. As he does, a man comes up to S and pauses next to him - at first, we see only the man's legs blows ominously as Skippy looks down to see the two flat face falls as he looks up to see Burke, hands in his pock him grimly.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: This map will reappear throughout the film to mark the sh Three points on the map are identified: Hong Kong, Honolu Francisco. A superimposed text reads: Ist DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears in the c heading east on the high seas.

dialogues.speaker: CABIN DOOR
dialogues.text: A brief glimpse of the door to cabin B-55 upon which hang DISTURB sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which allows us to see a handwritten addition: "By Doctor

dialogues.speaker: A TRAY
dialogues.text: loaded with medicines, powders and pills -- the sort of t terminal heart patients.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No more parties. No more cigarettes. No more dancing. And no more cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN AND HER DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Joan sits glumly as the doctor stands over her, trying to

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You're cutting your months into weeks, your weeks into days--

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: And my days into hours. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What you really mean -- and you're too kind to say -- is that if I stay in my stateroom, lie in bed, deny myself everything, even the - the mildest diversion, I may live to arrive at that charming sanitarium.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You state it very cruelly. Joan rises and crosses to her cabin's window. She looks o

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It's not a pretty picture, is it? (reluctantly) All right. All right, doctor. I'll do what you say. (chuckles) Funny how we cling to life even after it's worthless. Joan hears the sound of Dan's voice drifting in through t

dialogues.speaker: DAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: She's about so tall, black hair, large brown eyes. Her first name is Joan. Peering through the window, Joan sees Dan walking the dec Delighted, she watches them pass and then turns back to t

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No, I was wrong. I know now what I want. I want to crowd all the intense, beautiful happiness possible into what life I've got left. That's all living's for. If it's only for a few hours, I want to have it. And I'm going to have it -- all I can get my hands on. Joan leaves the window, moves toward the door. The doctor

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Joan, I--

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Now, doctor, I am going on deck.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: But, Jo--

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Goodbye! With a huge smile, she breaks away from him and is instan slamming it shut behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: sits at the bar as a young bartender mixes him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (to Dan) I don't know, she might've been in here, but I didn't notice her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enters the lounge and looks around anxiously. She spots

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: who is busy lighting a cigarette and fails to see her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Mm, then she wasn't here. You'd've noticed her. JOAN, smiling radiantly, checks her hair and then moves t

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Joan joins Dan at the bar, approaching him from behind so her. The bartender, having just poured Dan's drink, now l work and notices her. He raises his eyebrows and smiles in rec She indicates with a gesture that he should pour her the he promptly does, with a grin. The bartender watches with puts his glass to his lips at the same moment Joan speaks to h

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Dan. Dan turns and looks at her, pleased and surprised. We hea

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The luck's come back. Dan nods, noticing that, once again, they both hold the s

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This time, in full glasses.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: We mustn't lose a drop, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (toasts her) Health. A dark look crosses Joan's face. She recovers with a smil

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Luck. Once again, they swallow their drinks, never taking their another. They exchange grins. The bartender smiles warmly at this. Joan, holding her glass by the stem, smashes it against The bartender's eyes pop in surprise. Joan places her stem on the countertop. Then, Dan smashes The startled bartender flinches. As before, Dan crosses his stem with Joan's. They smile a TRUCK FORWARD for a CLOSER VIEW of the crossed stems on t between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and Joan stand at the railing together watching the s

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The day knows how to go out. Ina blaze of glory. Forgive me if I'm going poetic on you. But life is wonderful, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: And its best moment is when we find it out. Joan thinks about this a moment and then turns to look at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship sails east under a night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and Burke, in dinner clothes, stand outside the ship' through the well-lit windows. Classical piano music. The through a nearby door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smartly-dressed crowd listens as an attractive, aristoc elegantly plays a grand piano. We get a CLOSE VIEW of the woman, kn passengers as Countess Bettina de Barilhaus, but whom we short. Dan and Burke arrive as Betty concludes her number. The rises and catches sight of Dan and Burke. Burke stares at Dan lowers his eyes and tries to look bored. Betty, carrying an expensive fan, joins her stiff British monocled nobleman named SIR HAROLD.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (pleasantly, with a vaguely European accent) Now, we must be going. Sir Harold nods and the two begin to walk off together. M groan and protest, "Aw, Countess ..." "Please!" —- but sh politely.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. You'll forgive me. I'm very fatigued. Some other time. But before she can get away a bejeweled dowager stops her

dialogues.speaker: DOWAGER
dialogues.text: Oh, Countess, are you of the Bavarian Barilhauses?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (coolly) Mm, the elder son.

dialogues.speaker: DOWAGER
dialogues.text: I had the pleasure in meeting them last summer.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (unenthusiastic) Delightful. We must have tea together some time. Betty moves off. Sir Harold follows like a puppy dog.

dialogues.speaker: SIR HAROLD
dialogues.text: Countess, you play divinely. As she passes, Betty ignores Burke but pauses ever so sli look at Dan who pointedly shows no sign of recognizing he Betty, struck by her beauty. Betty and Sir Harold stand apart from the others.

dialogues.speaker: SIR HAROLD
dialogues.text: Shall I see you ... later, Countess?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Not tonight, Sir Harold. Tomorrow night, I promise you.  Betty puts her hand in his.

dialogues.speaker: SIR HAROLD
dialogues.text: I shall live ... in anticipation. Sir Harold kisses Betty's hand grandly. Burke jealously watches all this with interest -- it's no activity a Frisco cop sees much of.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (amused, to Burke) Don't let the royalty get you down. Dan moves off as Burke smiles self-consciously and gives wave. Fanning herself, Betty watches Sir Harold walk away. He p delivers a courtly bow to her. She nods in reply and they another. As they do, Skippy abruptly enters and nearly bu face lights up with recognition:

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Well! If it ain't-- Skippy offers a hand in greeting. But Betty ignores this, both her voice and her European accent:

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (American accent) Play dead, chump. Tail me to my joint. Skippy watches with surprise as Betty, fanning herself, b puts on his hat and nonchalantly strolls after her.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Burke joins the same young bartender who waited on Dan an Self- conscious about his garlic breath, Burke screws up his fa Dan's direction while deciding what to order.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Something I can do for you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (unhappily) Buttermilk.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Bartender pulls out a tall glass and a pitcher of butterm

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Say, pal, will ya do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: What do you call a countess when you wanna speak to her?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hmm. (unconvincingly) "Madame la Countesse." We PAN DOWN the bar to another bartender who assembles an bottles, glasses, ice, and other mixings. A steward takes carries it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steward arrives at the cabin door with the elaborate After a moment, he opens the door and enters, placing the Also visible on the table are Skippy's feet which are pro Skippy tosses a coin onto the tray -- a tip for the stewa

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Thank you! The steward takes the coin and departs, closing the door takes his feet down off the table, reaches over and grabs from the tray. We see his smiling face for the first time as h and brings it to his lips. He chugs the contents. And chu We CUT WIDE to reveal that Betty is lounging nearby on a After a moment, she speaks to him -- not with her fancy E with her tough American one.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Say, don't you ever breathe? Skippy stops drinking, exhales deeply, and hands Betty th the mouth of the bottle and takes a fairly long swig hers Skippy's surprise. Skippy looks over the tray with all it

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: What's the idea of all the landscape gardening?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (haughtily, using her fake European accent) Oh, straight gin is so vulgar, my dear -- (instantly lapsing  into Americanese) Oh, boy! Are my pups growling! Betty leans over and rubs her sore feet.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (amused) Betty, don't they ever get on to you? You've been gettin’ away with this for years. Who are ya supposed to be now?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sucker... (strips away her bangs) -.. meet Bettina, la Comtesse de Barilhaus. She tosses her fake bangs aside.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, Barilhaus. Oh, I get it! "Barrel House" Betty! Barilhaus, sure. Have you got anything lined up?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Mm, did ya get a load of that Englishman with the single cheater? She means, of course, Sir Harold and his monocle. Betty d and scours her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: I did. Full face, he looks like the Bank of England. Look, I had an idea--

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Now, lay off! No petty larceny in this one. Say, if I make this touch, I'm through. Sick of jumping every time there's a knock at the door. You know, this sticky stuff's bad for my scalp. Hm. Guess I'm just tired.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: You hustlers are all alike. Spend all your time in the twilight sleep. What've ya got on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Say, I'ma sucker, just like the rest of them. I want a chicken ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, I know that one, too. All you need is five thousand hens and one rooster.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: That's the set-up.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Stop kiddin' yourself, Betty. You'll be ridin' these tubs till they count ten over ya.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I may fool ya.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: I hope ya do. She takes a swig of gin and hands him back the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Spray your throat.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Here's to the rooster. Cluck, cluck, cluck, cluck, cluck. Betty chuckles as Skippy drinks

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Say, uh, who's the mug with Dan Hardesty?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: He's a copper. The toughest one out of Frisco.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Pinch?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Nothin' else.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Tough rap?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: The toughest.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (stunned) Murder?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: If you can call it murder for croakin'  the dirtiest heel that ever lived.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, any chance to beat the rap?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: No, no. He's already been sentenced.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, then, how's he-

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: He broke. He broke when they were takin' him to San Quentin.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (realizes what that means) The rope.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (soberly) The rope.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Whew. Shaken, Betty rises in disbelief and ends up at the cabin

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He's a swell guy, too. Gee, he came to the front for me in Singapore when I was in wrong. (with emphasis) And I was in wrong. (shakes her head) Took a long chance for me. (sighs) Certainly wish I could pay him back the same way. Betty sees something out the window and draws back the cu look. She glances over at Skippy, motions with her eyes f then continues to stare out.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Look. We hear Joan and Dan's theme as Skippy joins Betty at the crooks stand together and see:

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: standing at the ship's railing.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He's got everything. Strength, youth, courage. ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watch Dan and Joan glumly.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ... Everything that makes life fit to live. (beat) It's just a ghost. Skippy nods solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: stand at the railing and look out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan stares out at the water. Dan smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Is it late?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Does it matter? She turns to him with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Not any more. (dreamily) The world and time seem somewhere else. Dan moves in warmly to give Joan a kiss but before they d

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND SKIPPY
dialogues.text: watching at the window. Betty shuts the curtain and looks

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Death ain't tough enough. (beat) He's gotta fall in love.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: A dotted line, marking the ship's progress, stretches fro the way to Honolulu. San Francisco seems very far away at A superimposed text reads: 3rd DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears in the ce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and Burke, casually dressed, stand at the rail.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Let's take a turn around the deck. Dan shows no interest, calmly puffing a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I do forty laps a day. Keeps you in shape.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (dryly) What's the percentage of me keeping in shape?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Why, it's, uh, better than, uh, mooning around the deck all night. A smiling Joan appears in a doorway and heads for the men cigarette over the side and tips his cap as he takes Joan

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Oh, good morning.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: May I present Mr. Burke? Miss Ames.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: How do you do? Joan and Burke shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Burke is an old friend of mine. We're ... traveling together.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: How nice.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're together all the time.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Practically inseparable.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (pleasantly, to Burke) Well, I'm taking him for the afternoon. (drags Dan away) Come along, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: That's all right. Burke watches them go, then takes a few deep breaths and around the deck. Farther down the deck, we see

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: sitting in a lounge chair with a book in hand. She grins

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: standing nearby. He readies himself and then adopts a dru staggering forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skippy staggers down the deck and pretends to lose his ba top of Betty who screams. Skippy, sitting on her legs, ti apologetically as Burke strides into view, grabs Skippy's him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Hey, you little tramp! I ought to throw you overboard! Burke shoves Skippy who wobbles away.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: sighs, whimpers, and employs her European accent, pretend in distress to engage Burke's sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Isn't it possible for a lady to to go anywhere nowadays without bumping into all sorts of people?!

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: peers around a corner at Burke and Betty.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: hollers at Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: If I had you on shore, I'd--!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (whimpers, clutches her throat) Oh, I'm so frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tips his cap) Nobody's gonna harm you.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Ah, you are good. So brave. I am very, very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (genuinely pleased) Aw, don't mention it, eh, Madame la Countess.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, you know me, huh? Who I am? I have not the pleasure to know you.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, my name's Steve Burke.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Delighted. Monsieur Burke. Betty offers Burke her hand. He is about to bend over to looks around self-consciously and decides instead to shake it v invites him to sit in the lounge chair next to her.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Now, come, you sit down with me for a few minutes, hm? (Burke sits) Oh, that terrible man, he might come back.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Aw, nobody's gonna bother you -- not with me here.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You know, I could not feel safer if I thought you were a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Say, now, listen, lady ... Burke takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: watching from around the corner, laughs his irritating la heads off to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar, a patron downs a drink and then walks away, arrives. Seeing that the bartender at the cash register h to him, Skippy, left alone with the patron's empty glass and bottle of liquor, pours himself a drink. He knocks it back rapid hat to keep it from falling off. He quickly sets the glas look nonchalant. Seeing that the bartender is still busy at the register, another shot, downs it fast, and resumes his nonchalant p ignores the glass and simply grabs the bottle to chug dow Satisfied, he exhales deeply, grins, hiccups, buttons his move off. At last, the bartender, hands full of money, turns from t sees Skippy trying to leave unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hey...!

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Almost forgot. My change. The bartender raises his eyebrows in surprise and squints

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, sir? What was it you gave me?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: I gave ya a five dollar bill. The bartender counts out the change.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I'm - I'm sorry, sir. Sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, wait, you only took off for one drink. I had three. Skippy shoves some of the change back.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, sir, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Think nothing of it, my good man. The smiling bartender watches Skippy walk off with the mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drunken Skippy bumbles down the hallway toward a full- mistakes his own reflection for an oncoming passenger, an to let the person pass. He takes off his hat and bows apo

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. After a pause, he straightens and heads toward the mirror as before, he mistakes his own reflection for an oncoming a little, takes off his hat and bows.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: After you, sir. Another pause. Skippy straightens and again heads toward his reflection, and backs away. This time another passenger a by. Skippy looks up at the man.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (annoyed, to the man) Say, how long is this parade gonna last? Puzzled, the man looks at Skippy for a moment, says nothi

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (to the man) Oh, you won't talk, huh? Skippy snaps his fingers with contempt at the departing m heads back toward the mirror -- where he once again runs This time, he raises a hand in protest.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: No, you don't! No, you don't!

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY, (MIRROR NOT VISIBLE)
dialogues.text: Skippy beats his chest.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: It's my turn now! Skippy adjusts his jacket, barges forward and smashes int shattering it with a crash.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY AND THE BROKEN MIRROR
dialogues.text: We discover him on hands and knees amid broken shards of himself.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Well, you got away with it that time. But I know what you look like. And it won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: The dotted line, marking the ship's progress, stretches f to Honolulu. A superimposed text reads: 16th DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears in the ce heading toward the camera on a foggy night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of VIEWS of sailors dressed warmly, sporting bin into the fog-enshrouded night as a fog horn blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starting with a tuba (matched to the fog horn), we PAN OV orchestra as it plays dance music. Then, we PAN OVER to t in the lounge. Betty dances with Sir Harold but smiles at one side watching her. He scowls a little, annoyed and pu dancing with another man. We PAN OVER to Dan and Joan, also on the dance floor, in song ends. Nearly everyone breaks and applauds the musicians. stay in each others' arms and regard one another lovingly. The next number begins, a livelier uptempo piece. Sir Har dance with Betty but Burke muscles in, brusquely grabs Sir Haro pushes him away, showing no regard for etiquette. Betty merely h to Sir Harold who nods politely and watches as Burke grab away with her. Betty and Burke turn out to be the best rubber-legged dan Skippy, hat in hand, watches the couple from the sideline Burke puts a lot of energy into his eccentric dance moves Skippy points and laughs his irritating laugh. Burke and Betty pause at the sound of the laugh to stare But he just keeps laughing at them. Betty smiles as Burke gives Skippy a long dirty look. The  energetically. A grim Sir Harold watches all this unhappily, fanning him fan. After a moment, he peers down at the fan, realizes h and folds it up. DAN AND JOAN, meanwhile, are also still on the floor. On the sidelines, Joan's doctor watches the two of them w clearly overexerting herself. Joan looks stricken, pauses, and leans on Dan for support

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan. Dan, wait.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear. What is it, sweet?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm all right. Let's - let's go out on deck.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, dear. As the music ends and the crowd applauds, Dan helps Joan doctor, seeing this, shakes his head sadly and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the ship's orchestra plays their love theme, Dan and J the fog.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Better?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Much better. Out here.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: It is rather nice to get away from people, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Dan, I'm so happy. Dan kisses Joan's hand affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, Honolulu. I have the whole day planned. First, we'll hire a car. Drive across the Pali. Just we two, hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You don't sound very enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Only because ... There's something that may prevent my going ashore.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Dan. And I'd counted on it so.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry, I'll get out of it somehow.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Sweetheart. Betty and Burke emerge on deck, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Think you can lose friend Steve?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (wryly) I'll make it my supreme effort. Joan laughs. Betty and Burke approach Dan and Joan.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (to Betty) I can't dance with everybody -- but with you, Countess--

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (amused, to Joan) You know, Steven dances like a gigolo.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say that exactly. You two ain't so bad yourselves. Why aren't you going at it?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm saving my strength for tomorrow in Honolulu. Dan's taking me for a long drive. Burke doesn't like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (to Dan) Oh, so you're going for a long ride, huh?  Dan averts his eyes. Betty senses the need to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: That's swell.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I think I need a lemonade. Come Steven. (to Joan) We'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Au revoir. Dan politely rises as Betty and Burke move off.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND BURKE
dialogues.text: stroll down the deck. Burke is moody.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Steven?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I wonder if that guy back there thinks he's pulling me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Why? What about? They pause. Burke decides to level with her

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I may as well tell ya now. We ain't pals. He's my prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Wha-at? You are a police officer?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Sergeant, First Grade.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (pretends to be impressed Oh! Ohhh.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: And I know what's going on in that guy's mind like I can open it and look in it.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, you're wonderful! You know, I always wanted to meet a detective.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Honolulu's the last stop. That means it's his last chance to make a get-  away. And that's what that guy's thinkin', thinkin' every moment. But he's only wastin' his time.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: Joan tells Dan her plans for the next day.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Cross the island, I - I know the most divine spot. I'll take you there. Have you all to myself. Dan and Joan kiss, deeply, passionately.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND BURKE
dialogues.text: continue their conversation farther down the deck

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Let him once get near the shore and he'll risk his life to make a getaway. But if he makes one phony move ... Burke shows Betty his holstered pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (laughs nervously) Oh, you frighten me. What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna put him in the brig.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Brig? What is "brig"?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: That's what they call a jail ona ship.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (understands) Mmmm. The two stroll off, arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan sees Joan to her door. She opens it and they regard e

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Good night, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Good night, Joan. We hear their theme again briefly as Joan starts into he hand and kisses it as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Until tomorrow. Joan closes her door and Dan heads off down the hall, los

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fog horn blows as Dan, in coat and cap, walks the deck, officer salutes him but he pays little heed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty opens the door for Skippy who enters and looks arou closes the door behind him and crosses to a table. Skippy

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Betty scoops a half dozen bullets off the table into her to a delighted Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: From the copper's gun? How'd you get "em? Betty merely glances over to a nearby chair. Burke's bow it. In the background: an unmade bed. Skippy starts to la his mouth to hush him.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Now, get this. You go to Dan Hardesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fog horn. Skippy, concealed between some lifeboats, ste the deck and sees Dan approaching. As Dan nears, Skippy e the shoulder and instantly retreats. Dan looks around to being watched and joins Skippy between the lifeboats.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: You're slated for the brig, any minute.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I was afraid of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, look. Skippy shows Dan a handful of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: From Burke's gun?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Betty pulled his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: That gives me a chance. Skippy whips out a wad of bills and hands it to Dan.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Hey, here's a bankroll. You'll need it. Compliments of Betty.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: English money?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Well, that's the only kind Sir Harold had.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What a girl.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Come on, Dan, get goin’.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: All the luck in the world, pal.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'll need it. Dan hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: The dotted line, marking the ship's progress, stretches f Honolulu. A superimposed text reads: 17th DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears in the ce heading east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning. An officer shows Burke a cell in the brig.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: He won't get out of there. The officer hands Burke the key. Burke looks the cell ove

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can I help you bring him down?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: No, no, I don't need any help. I can handle him myself. The officer salutes and walks off. Burke gives the cell d satisfied, starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan sits at a desk, writing a letter which reads: Joan- I am running away - a fugitive condemned to death. I've tried to tell you but couldn't. I will attempt to reach Mexico. If you can forgive me, come to me there. If not, know that I understand and love you always. He signs it "Dan" and blots it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimmers approach the ship as it motors toward the shore. ship and into the water.

dialogues.speaker: IN DAN AND BURKE'S STATEROOM
dialogues.text: A British-accented steward stands by as Dan sits at the d  envelope and issuing instructions.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'd like you to deliver this to Miss Joan Ames in stateroom B-fifty-five -- about an hour after the ship docks in Honolulu.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (hands over the envelope) You understand? About an hour after we dock, not before that.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (rises) And ... don't disturb me for a couple of hours. I think I'll take a nap. I'll ring you if I want you.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. Dan watches the steward exit, then quickly grabs a heavy from a nearby table and dumps it out in the bathroom sink he grabs it and carries the decanter and the towel to the He places the decanter strategically on the table, then o twists it into a gag and places it against his mouth for it will gag Burke effectively, he hides it under a bed sheet

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL
dialogues.text: outside the cabin, Burke arrives. He pauses at the door, taking no chances, he draws his pistol and checks it. No out the clip: empty. He casts a suspicious look at the door.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Dan readies a rope with which to tie Burke.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL
dialogues.text: Scowling, Burke nods in understanding, guessing that Dan ammunition. He takes a fresh clip from his pocket, loads gun.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Dan hears Burke opening the door and stuffs the rope unde smoothing his hair, moves to a bureau and grabs a cigaret Burke staring at him grimly. Dan lights his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well, pal, you look pretty smooth. Going ashore?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, I'm sorry, pal. You're goin' in the brig. Burke moves casually into the bathroom. Dan, just as casu direction.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: That's a bit tough but ... I can't say I blame you. Burke, in the bathroom, keeps an eye on Dan in the bathro

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know how it is. A guy's gotta do his duty. Burke watches in the mirror as Dan sets down his cigarett heavy glass decanter. Burke reaches for his pistol. Dan raises the decanter and moves forward rapidly. Grinning, Burke spins and fires. The decanter shatters and Dan freezes, staring first at B broken glass in his upraised hand. Dan looks stunned and his hand and sighs at Burke.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Not bad. Burke covers Dan with his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: And now, if you've no serious objections, pal, let's get going.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No objections. Dan sets what's left of the decanter down. The two men mo exit.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL
dialogues.text: Passersby murmur noisily, having heard the sound of a gun his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: All right, pal, across the hall and down through the engine room. Ignoring passengers and officers, the two men walk off.  Watching all this from a corner is a worried Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW DECK
dialogues.text: Noises from the engine room reverberate as Dan and Burke flights of narrow stairs. They pass a good deal of machin bowels of the ship. Occasionally, Dan must pause to get d who stays behind him at all times. Finally, they arrive a Skippy trails behind, peering around a corner. Burke unlocks and opens the cell door, then points for Da enters and Burke locks him in. Burke starts to leave but something to Dan through the door.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Listen, sucker, the next time you take the shells out of a smart guy's gun, remember to put some blanks back! Skippy overhears this and watches closely as Burke pocket left-hand jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers disembark and file down the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stands near the purser's station reading a brochure past her and speaks rapidly out of the corner of his mout

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Dan is in the brig. The copper's got the key here. Skippy pats his his left-hand jacket pocket. Betty shows whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oke. Skippy wobbles off and takes up a position down the hall. gorgeous white dress for her day in Honolulu, joins Betty

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Good morning. I, er, I was just waiting for Mr. Burke to take me ashore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen Dan?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Uh, no, no, but he'll be along soon. Burke joins Betty and Joan.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Good morning, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Burke. Betty immediately coos over Burke and runs her hands over

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (to Joan) Oooh. Doesn't he look handsome? Betty easily picks Burke's pocket and palms the key. Skip from a distance, laughs his annoying laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Have you seen Dan anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) Why, er-- No, I - I haven't. (to Betty) We gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: See you ashore.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Sure. Burke and Betty walk toward the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Gee, that was a tough spot.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Mm, poor kid-- (catches herself, switches to French) Le pauvre enfant, hm? As they pass Skippy, Betty hands him the key, then puts h Skippy looks at it with delight and hurries off to free D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Betty are among the passengers filing down the

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BRIG
dialogues.text: Skippy unlocks and opens the cell door. An amazed Dan app

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: The cop and Betty have gone ashore. Give them plenty of time for a head start. Dan is speechless. He grips Skippy's shoulders warmly and a word. Skippy watches him go, then shuts and locks the cel

dialogues.speaker: BELOW DECK
dialogues.text: Dan strides past the heavy machinery and climbs the narro deck.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GANGPLANK
dialogues.text: Joan looks around with concern for Dan.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW DECK
dialogues.text: Dan hustles up the stairs, then slows to a walk as he rea

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GANGPLANK
dialogues.text: Joan moves off in search of Dan. Dan rounds a corner and sees the empty gangplank. He puts heads for it. But Joan spots Dan as he starts down.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan! Dan, startled, stops and turns. Joan joins him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Dan, oh, I've been looking all over for you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, but I--

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It's all right now that you're here now. Well, come on. Let's go, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. They start down the gangplank. Joan opens her parasol.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Wait'll I get this up. There we are. They descend the gangplank. Dan's eyes shoot around nervo they meet Joan's doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Hardesty.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Doctor. Dan looks around uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (to Joan) Now, please be careful. Not too strenuous today.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Don't you worry about me, old dear. (taking Dan's arm) Come along, Dan. (to the doctor) Bye! The doctor watches them skeptically as they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke and Betty stroll along, chatting amiably. Skippy ru and blunders into them. In the process, Skippy separates them long enough to pass the key to Betty who, sobbing and cli pretense of fear, stealthily returns the key to Burke's p

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (angrily, to Skippy) When you get to Frisco, I'll bounce you in the can so fast, you won't come out till Chinese New Year!

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Buddy, when I get back to Frisco, you'll be trippin' over your beard! Skippy laughs his inimitable annoying laugh and walks off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and Joan park a rented car in front of a spectacular which fly in the stiff tropic breeze. Dan climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Now, if you don't mind waiting for just a couple of moments, I have a little surprise for you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan speaks to an ape-jawed bartender.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So I've got to get out of here today.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (nods) I see. (thinks) I've got the man. Have you got plenty of money? Dan shows him his wad of English bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at a table, Dan shows the wad of bills to another ship's captain. Dan passes him some cash under the table pockets it. The two men rise and Dan follows the captain the captain gestures.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: There she is. You can't miss it. Dan looks and sees: a steamship at anchor.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: What time do we sail?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Just as soon as it's dark.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: We'll be ready to shove off the minute you step aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Good. The two men go their separate ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, still seated in the parked car by the flags, smiles She sighs in delight at a giant lei, dense with flowers, presents to her as he climbs in next to her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Gardenias, [pekakee?] and camillia.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It's too beautiful. Dan puts the car in gear.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Now, over the Pali. [?]

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We're off. They drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and Joan sit together in some sheltered spot with bea scenery for a backdrop. Dan, pensive, smokes a cigarette. Joan, d lounges against a tree, wearing the lei. Hawaiian guitars

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I could stay here forever.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I wonder.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Would you be content to spend the rest of your life with me in some ... far-away place?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Anywhere, Dan. He looks at her, wondering how to break the news to her.  and sits up to question him more closely.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Why so serious?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Joan, dear, I've got to tell you this.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan, if it's serious, I don't want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: But I must tell you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Not today.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: But, my dear-- She puts a finger to his lips and shushes him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: May I have a cigarette? He reluctantly breaks eye contact with her and fishes out

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You're incorrigible. She takes a cigarette. He taps some ash off the end of hi hers. As she exhales, they stare into one another's eyes and then slowly draw in for a passionate kiss. After a moment cigarette and flicks it away. We PAN WITH the half-smoked the nearby sand. After a pause, Joan's barely-smoked butt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skippy stands in a shop doorway, looking around. He sees approaching him on the sidewalk. Skippy looks thoughtful pulls out a half dollar, which he flips in the air like a the coin a kiss for luck, then drops it on the sidewalk i instantly turns his back to Sir Harold, assumes a nonchal whistling. Sir Harold approaches, sees the coin, pauses, steps on it smugly, then bends to pick it up. As he does, he exposes back pocket. Skippy, whistling, turns casually, plucks th Harold's pocket and strolls away with it. Sir Harold, not robbed, straightens with a satisfied smile, pockets the c Skippy, chuckling his inane laugh to himself, pauses in a the contents of the wallet. He opens up the wallet expec find it empty.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, boy, it's dark in there. He throws the wallet down on the sidewalk in disgust. Ang counts to ten to hold his temper.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, TEN! As he reaches ten, Skippy rounds a corner and spots Sir H

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Four dollars, please. Skippy watches Sir Harold pull out a wad of cash from his Skippy keeps counting, through gritted teeth, as he stalk

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twilight. Hawaiian guitars play. We open on the two cigar sand, then PAN OVER to a deeply satisfied Dan and Joan. H tree and holds her in his arms as she lies in his lap, lo another, very much in love. Joan sighs a little.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: This is living, isn't it, Dan? He leans his head against the tree and shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Could we ask for more?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) Only ... that it would never end. It won't end, will it, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (reassuring) My dear, whatever happens, we belong to each other, always.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hold me closer. They embrace. And kiss. And kiss. When they break, she ru cheek. He takes her hand and kisses it. They look out at spectacular sunset. Dan notices Joan's moist eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What's this? Tears? Oh ...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Can't help feeling a little bit sad. It's been such a happy day. I guess we ... we ought to go back, shouldn't we?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Reluctantly, he rises and helps her to her feet. They wal sun sinks down into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship's horn blows as Dan and Joan drive up in their r

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The dock's over there, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, it's still there.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The gangplank's there. We can - we can make it if we hurry. They climb out. Dan takes Joan in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Joan, dear.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan, we have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I've got to tell you this.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You must go the rest of the way alone.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to tell you all day. I'm not going back on the ship. Joan's face falls, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You're ... not going back on the ship?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I can't go back, dear. Because I'm-- Joan's heart gives out -- she faints, collapsing into his

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: My dear? Joan? Dear? But she is unconscious. A ship's horn blows. Dan looks up chartered steamship anchored nearby. He glances down at Joan in his arms, then turns to see th front of him. Joyful Hawaiian music plays. Passengers line the deck, to waving "Aloha!" Also on deck: Joan's doctor, who peers at worriedly. Dan glances at his steamship, and at Joan who clearly nee attention, then makes a decision. He hoists Joan up and starts to ca Maloa just as a friendly Hawaiian man approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HAWAIIAN MAN
dialogues.text: Might I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, will you turn that car around? And -- keep the engine going!

dialogues.speaker: HAWAIIAN MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Dan rushes off toward the gangplank with Joan in his arms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On deck, Burke and Betty lean on the railing, watching th suddenly spot Dan on the dock hauling Joan in his arms. I feels in his pocket for the brig key, pulls it out and lo fully aware of what's happening, keeps a stone face. Dan carries Joan up the gangplank which is festooned wit doctor meets him and they hurry off to Joan's cabin. Burke, grim, pockets the key and rushes off -- without a after a moment, follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor opens the cabin door for Dan who carries Joan on the bed. The lively Hawaiian melody gives way to the m Oe" as the doctor quickly examines her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Is she all right, Doctor? After a moment, the doctor looks at Dan and nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I believe so. Dan starts to withdraw. Joan looks like death warmed over look and turns to go. But Joan, without opening her eyes, regains consciousness him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan ... He pauses and reluctantly returns to the bed, leaning ove

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, dear? She can't open her eyes but somehow has the strength to p him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan ... Don't leave me ... The ship's horn blows noisily. Dan looks around, realizin the ship. He strokes her hair and presses his cheek to he manages a smile. The doctor, pleased at this, withdraws. Dan pulls away from her, seeing that Joan has fallen unco Burke brusquely enters the cabin but pauses at the sight bedside. Clearly, Dan isn't going anywhere. Joan's hand f side. Burke turns away thoughtfully and slowly exits, tak the couple before quietly closing the cabin door behind h

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL
dialogues.text: Burke fails to see Betty standing behind him as he shuts talks to himself, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Poor guy.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What did you say? Startled, Burke turns to see Betty. He is immediately sel

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn't say nothin'. Betty watches as Burke, flustered, walks off. After a mom down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CABIN
dialogues.text: As Dan watches over an unconscious Joan, he notices an en stand: the farewell letter he had written to her early th Somewhere off screen, a chorus of singers croons "Aloha Oe" as Dan and pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: Streamers fly as a sour-faced Burke leans against the rai crowd. A sympathetic Betty joins him and takes his hand a maintains her European accent even as she tells him:

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Ah, you're a swell guy, Steve. She rests her head on his shoulder. Burke gives her a puz brightens a little and straightens up. The two look down

dialogues.speaker: THE GANGPLANK
dialogues.text: being unhooked from the ship. A huge crowd of well-wisher waving to passengers on deck and singing "Aloha Oe." Burs crowd is Skippy, wearing a lei. He races up the streamer-clogge it is pulled away and jumps onto the ship, well ahead of policemen chasing him. Left stranded at the dock, they sh and yell for him to "Get out!" and "Don't come back!"

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: Burke rushes away from an amused Betty to join Skippy at doorway. Skippy points to the policeman.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Don't forget to write now, will ya? Skippy laughs his annoying laugh as a grim-looking Burke, strides into view behind him. Skippy turns to see Burke a laugh. Smugly, Burke nods and gives Skippy a sneering smi

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: The next stop, sucker, is San Francisco. Without a word, Skippy adjusts his jacket and wobbles off

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: pulls away from the dock as the crowd waves and finishes

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: The dotted line, marking the ship's progress, stretches f direction of San Francisco. A superimposed text reads: 19th DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears in the ce heading northeast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan lies half-asleep in bed. Joan's doctor sits at his be

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to disturb you. Dan awakens and sits up, with concern.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: It's you, Doctor--

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing's happened. I just want to have a little talk with you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You're the only one that can help me. (shakes his head sadly) Her condition is desperate. She must have absolute quiet and rest if she's to reach the mainland alive. She survived this attack but it isn't humanly possible for her to survive another. The slightest excitement might kill her. A shock surely would. Can I depend upon you?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now, try and get a little more rest. The doctor rises and heads for the door. Dan reaches a de out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Doctor. Dan rises and the doctor rejoins him.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I've got to tell you this. There IS a shock coming. And I don't know how to avoid it. When we reach San Francisco, I'll be met by the police. They're taking me to San Quentin ... for murder. The doctor stares at him, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: The dotted line, marking the ship's progress, stretches f about three-quarters of the way to San Francisco. A superimposed text reads: 22nd DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears in the ce heading northeast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN ALONG a row of lounge chairs to discover Dan and J dressed warmly against the chilly ocean breeze, a shared covering their legs. Joan, recovering but restless, is in

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'll play you a game of pegs.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I think you'd better rest.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (chuckles) You're beginning to even look like my doctor. We PAN FARTHER DOWN the deck to discover Sir Harold aslee noisily. Skippy, sitting beside him, sees this, then chu hands greedily as he sidles up to his sleeping victim, pr pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skippy, cautiously looking around, walks to Betty's door knock. Inside, Betty, brushing her hair, pauses, goes to the doo careful not to be seen from the hall. Skippy enters, look the door.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh. Betty closes the door behind Skippy and goes back to brus pulls out a wad of money and counts out some bills.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Shouldn't come here.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Nobody saw me. I came to pay you the money I owe you. Betty inspects the bills: English pounds.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sir Harold?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Thought I told you to lay off him.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Well, what was the use of lettin! him go to waste? You weren't usin! him.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I've been busy.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. With that copper. (wags a finger at her) You know, I think you're falling for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not such a bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Ah, sure. Copper-lover! Falling for the Law. The fox falling in love with the hounds. I'm ashamed of ya. I tell ya, that guy's no good.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute. His racket! son the other side of the fence but he's playing it on the up and up. He's one hundred percent copper just the same as you're one hundred percent thief. And, you know yourself, a hundred percent puts you at the head of the class.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: I wonder if I'm hearing all this right. Betty pointedly folds up the bills and stuffs

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Scram. Skippy tips his hat as he retreats and exits.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Good night, Countess. them down her front. Left alone, a smiling Betty brushes her hair even more vi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skippy rushes up to the bar in great excitement.
