dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Quick, bartender, give me a drink, quick!

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Quick! Before the fight begins!

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Here you are, sir. The bartender rapidly pours a shot which Skippy knocks ba Agitated, Skippy looks off, then back to the puzzled bart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Gimme another, another one, quick. Quick! Before the fight begins! The bartender pours another shot.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Wait a minute! What fight?! Skippy knocks back the second drink.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: (suddenly calm) The fight between you and me. I can't pay for these drinks. The bartender watches with amazement as Skippy laughs his staggers away.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: The dotted line, marking the ship's progress, stretches a Honolulu to San Francisco. A superimposed text reads: 24th DAY A superimposed image of the S. S. Maloa appears over the the San Francisco Bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan and Joan stand at the deck. Bells ring.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: The Golden Gate.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I remember an old hymn. How'd it go? "Keep those golden gates wide open ..."

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: "Keep those gates ajar ..."

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember that. I was born here in San Francisco. And when I was a youngster, I used to think they were singing about this Golden  Gate. I thought it was the only one.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I hope you were wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (nods) I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the city as seen by Dan and Joan from the bay. Whistle

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: taking in the view.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Lovely, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: lost in thought. VISIONS of SAN QUENTIN and a silhouetted SUPERIMPOSED across his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: stand silently together at the railing, both lost in thou

dialogues.speaker: BURKE AND BETTY
dialogues.text: emerge on deck, walking side by side to the railing in an ship.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Voila! Your San Francisco, hm? Home.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (unhappy) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ROOM
dialogues.text: A headphone-wearing radio operator hands a newly-received steward.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Here, get a load of this. As an ominous horn blows, the steward reads the telegram:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steward hands the message back to the radio operator envelope for delivery.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: I've seen some royalty in my time but I thought she was the grandest of the lot. I hate to deliver it. Amused, the radio operator hands the envelope to the stew exits the radio room with it and heads off grimly down th

dialogues.speaker: BURKE AND BETTY
dialogues.text: standing together at the rail.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: You know, I'm sort of tired of bein' a copper. Betty looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. I - I just sort of feel that I won't enjoy being the Law any more, after what's happened. And I was wondering if you'd be, well, I sort of - I sort of thought that-- Well, anyway, I got a ranch half paid for.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: A ranch?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Sure. I got a chicken ranch in Petaluma. Betty is, of course, stunned. She reaches a decision.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd love it, Steven, but-- There's something I have to tell you, first. (drops her phony accent) Aw, you're a right guy and I'm gonna come clean with ya. Now, it is Burke's turn to be stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: In the first place, I'm not a countess-— Abruptly, the steward arrives and hands Burke the envelop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg your pardon, sir. Betty turns away in embarrassment. Even as he stares at h the envelope and waves off the steward who departs. Burke ope reads it. He looks up and squints at Betty, then crumples fist.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (darkly) You were sayin'? Betty turns back to him, bluntly.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I was sayin' I'm not any of the things you think I am. I've been a long way. And I've left a wide trail.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: If it's your past, mine ain't been no bed of violets. Burke takes Betty's hand and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: What do you say we forget about it? Let's start from scratch.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You on the level, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: On the level. What do you say ... "Countess"?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Don't smear my bangs. They kiss. Behind his back, Burke drops the crumpled tele

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: Smiling into each other's eyes, they stand at the bar, ho

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Remember our first?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We thought it was our last. You never can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four glorious weeks. So many happy hours. And there's so many more, too. Aren't there, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Of course, dear.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Mustn't miss one of them. Dan offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We won't, dear. Joan takes his hand. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Where shall we dine tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Not as long as we're together but ... it's fun to plan ahead. Let's see. I'd like to ... to be in Caliente for New Year's.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: That's just a month, isn't it? Well, then. (a toast) Here's to Agua Caliente, New Year's Eve. They are suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Nothing can keep me away.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Nor me. They clink glasses gently and drink, never taking their e They drain their glasses and break into smiles again. And glasses on the side of the bar -- simultaneously. THE BARTENDER, nearby, winces.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: cross the stems on the countertop. THE BARTENDER, frustrated, snatches up two glasses in fro them to the floor with a crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits reading a magazine nearby. He looks up to see:

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: exiting the lounge, arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: nods to Dan, making eye contact

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: looks at Burke, knowing his time is up. Dan turns to Joan

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'll finish packing and ... join you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: All right, sweet. Joan smiles and exits. Dan watches her go, then turns and Burke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers line the deck as the ship pulls up to the nois

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan checks her wristwatch and looks out the window at th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke, holding the handcuffs, confers with Dan.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dan. Dan peers down unhappily at the cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You have to use those? Behind the two men, the British steward appears in the do overhears:

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I've got to deliver you according to Hoyle. You know, this ain't any petty larceny rap, it's murder. The steward raises his eyebrows at the word "murder." He as Dan pulls up his sleeve and Burke puts on the cuffs. Q turns and walks off, unnoticed by either Burke or Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: If we could get off the boat without her seeing us--

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Let's go. The two men head for the door. Dan picks up his overcoat their arms, concealing the cuffs. He picks up his hat and door open wide so that they may leave. After a pause, the men leading the way.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: stands in her cabin, looking unwell. She turns and exits TRACK WITH her as she walks nervously along, glancing aro Dan. She heads down a stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE
dialogues.text: arrive at a purser's station on their deck, preparing to

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: descends the stairwell and arrives at Dan's door. She's j when she hears the voice of the British steward coming fr

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You could have knocked me down with a belaying pin. And then, as nice as you please, he put the handcuffs on him. Joan, confused, knocks.

dialogues.speaker: IN DAN AND BURKE'S STATEROOM
dialogues.text: the steward turns from the maid he is speaking to and ope enters and looks around in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Where's Mr. Hardesty?

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: I was just telling her, Miss. Right here, in front of my very eyes, his friend, his best pal, as you might rightly call him, takes out a pair  of handcuffs and -- snap, snap! -- and he's a prisoner. With their hands at their side, out they goes. Growing pale, Joan stares at the steward in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan?

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: The very same, Miss. And a nicer gentleman you wouldn't wish to meet. And him, a red-handed murderer. And here's me, bobbin' in and out of here, with no thought of me own life, turning me back on him. Why, he might have cut my throat from ear to ear. Before the steward can finish, Joan, breathing hard, stag door and leans in the doorway, eyes shut. After a moment, she horror, then desperately rushes back to the stairwell and stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE
dialogues.text: still at the purser's station. Dan glances around uncerta

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: having reached the top of the stairs, looks up and down t then we TRACK WITH her as she rushes in the direction of

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE
dialogues.text: still at the purser's station.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: who struggles through the crowd of passengers, searching no sign of him. She clutches a hand to her head, then pre the mob.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE
dialogues.text: still at the purser's station.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: through the crowded deck. She pauses and puts a hand to h grows dizzy. The CAMERA MIRRORS her dizziness but she pre disappearing into the mob.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE

dialogues.speaker: AT A STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: The hallway is empty. Joan rushes into view and climbs th moment later, Dan and Burke emerge from the lower deck an gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: apparently lost. She ducks in a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND BURKE
dialogues.text: stuck in the line at the gangplank which has apparently n yet. They look around unhappily, unable to disembark righ

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: fails to see Joan appear several yards behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: sees Dan. She pauses, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: still hasn't noticed her.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: raises a hand to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dan!

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: hears her but doesn't want to look in her direction. Fina hear their theme.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Joan! He puts out his free hand to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: presses forward.

dialogues.speaker: DAN AND JOAN
dialogues.text: hold hands and stand together.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: peers into Dan's face, knowing she will never see him aga

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: shakes his head, with a slight grin.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Not goodbye, dear. Auf wiedersehen. Until New Year's Eve.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: glows happily. In the background, we hear the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Auf wiedersehen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: kiss deeply. Passengers begin to file out behind them, do They break the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: watches, smiling, as Dan, too, retreats toward the gangpl

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Nearly lost in the crowd. He looks back at her over the t waves, just as he had over the saloon's swinging doors wa

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: delighted, returns the wave.

dialogues.text: on the gangplank. Dan turns away from Joan. He and Burke WITH them for a moment and then PAN BACK UP, past the oth passengers, to

dialogues.speaker: A TOY BALLOON
dialogues.text: upon which is printed:

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY NEW YEAR
dialogues.text: A crowd roars and hollers, "Happy New Year!" A band plays a lively version of "Auld Lang Syne." Someone sticks a cigarette in the balloon and we hear but burst. Instead, we CUT TO a fast TRACKING SHOT that runs paralle part of the Agua Caliente resort in Tijuana, Mexico. The well-dressed revelers: tuxedoes and evening gowns and par and balloons and noisemakers are everywhere. They dance, at tables and order food, they make merry. We SWOOP PAST them all to the far end of the club which i Two bartenders stand together, polishing glasses at a bar bar, a lone figure sits on a stool. We don't recognize hi But then we abruptly leave our parallel track and RAPIDLY the man for a brief, seconds-long glimpse: it is Skippy a him before -- well-groomed in a black tux, nursing a drin sober, lost in thought. In a moment, he is gone and we catch a short view of the him as we PAN OVER to the two bartenders, wiping their gl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be glad when this thing's over.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You're telling me? These holidays are dynamite. They hear the sound of glasses shattering.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hey! Look out for them glasses with your elbow!

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (indignant) I never touched any glasses. Confused, the bartenders turn in the direction of the noi Joan's theme as we PUSH FORWARD and between the bartender stems of two broken glasses crossed on the countertop, da visible in the background. After a moment, the broken glass vanishes, ghost-like, in

dialogues.speaker: END TITLE
dialogues.text: Till We Meet Again Smile the while you kiss me sad adieu When the clouds roll by I'll come to you Then the skies will seem more blue Down in Lover's Lane, my dearie, Wedding bells will ring so merrily Ev'ry tear will be a memory So wait and pray each night for me Till we meet again  Where Was I? [Dan and Joan's love theme became a #1 pop hit in 1940 with Al Dubin's words set to W. Frank Harling's music. The song was introduced in “'Til We Meet Again" -- the 1940 remake of "One Way Passage"...] Oh, where was I The night that you surrendered to a sigh? Where was I? The moon was high The night that you first listened to a lie Where was I? I always felt that you would melt In someone's arms some night And I was right The moment came But what a shame that someone else came by Where was I?
